titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Macbeth Gallery Scrapbooks, 1892-1952, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Stephanie Ashley, Erin Corley and Jetta Samulski
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the digitization of this collection was provided by the Terra Foundation for American Art.

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Lee Anne Tuason 2008

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: Macbeth Gallery scrapbooks date from 1892-1952 and provide almost comprehensive coverage of the gallery's history and day-to-day events at the gallery. Documented are many of the gallery's exhibitions as well as the fortieth, fiftieth and sixtieth anniversaries, and news of the art world in general. The scrapbooks contain exhibition catalogs, invitations, announcements, price lists, related news clippings, and some photographs. The scrapbooks form part of the larger Macbeth Gallery records.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Described here are scrapbooks which form a part of the larger collection of the Macbeth Gallery records that were donated to the Archives in several installments between 1955 and 1966 by Robert G. McIntyre and Estate.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: The scrapbooks form a part of the larger Macbeth Gallery records, also located at the Archives of American Art.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Macbeth Gallery records are available at the Archives of American Art. Macbeth Gallery exhibition catalogs are also held by the Frick Art Reference Library and the Watson Library of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

altformavail.head: Alternative Forms Available
altformavail.p: The Macbeth Gallery scrapbooks were digitized in 2008 and are available via the Archives of American Art's website.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The microfilm of the Macbeth Gallery scrapbooks was digitized in 2008 and made available online. The scrapbooks form a part of the larger Macbeth Gallery records that were microfiled in several installments on reels NMc1-NMc81, 439-441, 2564-2667, 3091-3092, 3094, and 2820-2823. All accessions were merged and the collection was arranged according to archival standards in 2003-2004 by Stephanie Ashley, Erin Corley and Jetta Samulski with funding provided by the Getty Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Macbeth Gallery records, 1838-1968. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The microfilm of the scrapbooks has been digitized and is available online via AAA's website. The original scrapbooks are closed to researchers due to their fragile condition.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Macbeth Gallery records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Macbeth Gallery was established in 1892 by William Macbeth, a Scotch-Irish immigrant who had spent ten years with the print dealer Frederick Keppel before he opened his doors to the art-buying public at 237 Fifth Avenue in New York. Despite the prevailing interest in foreign art at that time, particularly in that of the Barbizon and Dutch schools, Macbeth was determined to dedicate his gallery to "the permanent exhibition and sale of American pictures, both in oil and water colors."
Although some of the gallery's earliest exhibitions were of work by European artists, the business soon became the only gallery in continuous operation to keep American art permanently on display.

In 1908, Macbeth undertook what was to become the major event in the gallery's early history: the 1908 exhibition of "The Eight," featuring work by Arthur B. Davies, Willam J. Glackens, Robert Henri, Ernest Lawson, George Luks, Maurice Prendergast, Everett Shinn, and John Sloan. "The Eight" were an unlikely combination of social realists, visionaries and impressionists eager to challenge the dominating influence of the National Academy. The exhibition received an immense amount of publicity and instantly entered into art history as a successful assault on tradition. While the exhibition is reviewed in newspaper clippings contained in the scrapbooks, the exhibition catalog is notably missing from the collection.

The history of the Macbeth Gallery is a long and distinguished one with each successive proprietor making a significant contribution to art in America. William Macbeth helped establish an audience and a market for American art when few were willing to give it serious consideration. Robert Macbeth continued to cement the gallery's reputation as one of the leading firms in New York and was instrumental in organizing the American Art Dealers Association. Robert G. McIntyre claimed in a letter to Lloyd Goodrich, dated 22 June 1945, that the thing of which he was most proud was "the share I have had in the formation of the collection of the Addison Gallery of American Art, at Andover, Massacusetts." McIntyre was widely respected in the art community as a dealer, as an adviser to curators, and as a scholar whose research and book on Martin Johnson Heade helped "rediscover" an important American artist. Note: A more detailed history of the gallery is found in the finding aid for the Macbeth Gallery records in the Archives of American Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Found here are twenty scrapbooks documenting Macbeth gallery's exhibitions and general history.

p.ref: See index for List of Macbeth Gallery Exhibitions documented in the scrapbooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as one series:

scopecontent.p: This series houses Macbeth Gallery scrapbooks which contain exhibition catalogs, announcements, invitations, price lists, related news clippings, and some photographs. The scrapbooks provide almost comprehensive coverage of the gallery's history and important exhibitions, as well as the fortieth, fiftieth and sixtieth anniversaries, and news of the art world in general. Many of the exhibition catalogs found here are annotated with prices and other notes. Although documented in news clippings found within the scrapbooks, the exhibition catalog for the gallery's 1908 exhibition of "The Eight" is notably missing from the collection.

The scrapbooks are extremely fragile as the material found here is mounted on highly acidic paper and much of the material has come loose from the scrapbook pages. Consequently the original format of the scrapbooks is closed to researchers.

odd.head: Index: List of Macbeth Gallery Exhibitions
odd.p: This chronological list of Macbeth Gallery exhibitions is extensive, but incomplete. While an attempt has been made to establish the accuracy of the information provided here, dates and titles of exhibitions are not guaranteed to be accurate. Most of the exhibitions listed here are documented in the scrapbooks through exhibition catalogs and/or invitations, lists of artwork and news clippings. The list is annotated with AAA microfilm reel and frame numbers to assist researchers in locating material on specific exhibitions.
